metadata.title: Fabrication of small <ce:small-caps>l</ce:small-caps>-threonine capped nickel nanoparticles and their catalytic application

Fig. 1 UV–vis spectra of fresh samples of Ni NPs prepared in aqueous environments by varying the concentration of reducing agent. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 2 FTIR spectra of (a) standard l-threonine and (b) l-threonine capped Ni NPs obtained after separation by centrifugation method. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 3 AFM images of well dispersed l-threonine capped Ni NPs at (a) low magnification and (b) high magnification. Fig. 4 Size distribution, formation and schematic of Ni NPs capped with l-threonine molecules. AFM and TEM micrographs were used for size calculations. Fig. 5 TEM images of l-threonine capped Ni NPs mounted on carbon coated Cu grids. The scale bar in the image is equal to 100nm. Fig. 6 Linear molecular structures of (a) CR dye, (b) its sulfonazo form and (c) chinone form produced during the course of reaction. Fig. 7 UV–vis spectra showing (a) CR dye (20μM) in Milli-Q water and (b) catalytic degradation of dye (20μM) with Ni NPs (0.2mg) deposited on glass cover slips in the presence of NaBH4 (0.1M). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 8 Recovery of l-threonine capped Ni NPs for four times to carry out reduction/degradation of congo red dye with negligible loss of efficiency. Fabrication of small l-threonine capped nickel nanoparticles and their catalytic application Nazar Hussain Kalwar a ⁎ Sirajuddin a Syed Tufail Hussain Sherazi a Abdul Rauf Khaskheli a Keith Richard Hallam b Thomas Bligh Scott b Zulfiqar Ali Tagar a Syeda Sara Hassan a Razium Ali Soomro a a National Centre of Excellence in Analytical Chemistry, University of Sindh, Jamshoro, 76080, Pakistan b Interface Analysis Centre, University of Bristol, Bristol BS2 8BS, United Kingdom ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +92 22 9213430; fax: +92 22 9213431. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Present study describes a new and simple approach to fabricate l-threonine capped Ni NPs. ► Our experiments showed development of highly efficient heterogeneous catalysts for reduction degradation of congo red dye. ► Congo red dye has been used as model compound as it gives different color shades in degraded and undegraded forms. ► Electron microscopy results in the formation of very small Ni NPs with homogeneous sizes and shapes and narrower size distributions. A facile and green seed mediated growth approach for fabrication of well dispersed l-threonine derived nickel nanoparticles (Ni NPs) in an aqueous medium via a modified borohydride reduction method is described. l-Threonine molecules served to organize the nanoscale composites in the form of well dispersed Ni NPs. The basic pH 8.5 was found to favor the formation of spherical and well dispersed Ni NPs as shown in transmission electron microscopy (TEM) micrographs. Freshly prepared Ni NPs possess the nanoscale dimension of 1.68–5.06nm, as determined from atomic force microscopy (AFM) and TEM data. The Ni NPs thus prepared were used for their catalytic potential in the reduction of congo red (CR) dye selected as a model reagent. The results revealed negligible reduction of dye in the absence of Ni NPs. Conversely the addition of only 0.2mg Ni NPs produced 100% reduction/degradation efficiency. The used Ni NPs were recovered and reutilized several times for reducing CR without any loss of activity. The current findings are equally extendable for safeguarding the aquatic environment against the pollution caused by other dyes via a facile, highly economical, rapid and efficient reduction/degradation method based on the catalytic potential of Ni NPs. Keywords l-Threonine Sodium borohydride Nickel nanoparticles Catalytic degradation Congo red 1 Introduction Nanotechnology continues to present newer materials and unique nanostructures with enhanced applications to benefit society in a greener way due to positive interactions of nanosized structures on health and environment. In view of the vast production of new materials, nanotechnologists are currently facing numerous challenges to encounter and discriminate potential harmful effects of nanomaterials [1]. Nanoscale objects with metallic, magnetic, conducting and semiconducting nature in a wide range of shapes and sizes have been easily fabricated by solution based synthetic routes [2]. Among all metal nanostructures Ni NPs have been found to be pragmatic for a number of applications, e.g. microwave absorbing materials, commercial batteries, magnetic recording media and formation catalysts [3]. The preparation of Ni NPs and their use as catalysts have been mentioned by many workers [4,5]. These procedures need high energy and special equipments for the formation of Ni nanoparticles. These nanoscale nickel catalysts are mainly synthesized by chemical reduction routes using different stabilizing agents such as polymers, surfactants, ligands, heterogeneous supports and bimolecular agents which are utilized to prevent the nanoscale objects from agglomerating [5]. The fabrication of materials with nanoscale dimensions having homogenous size distribution has also been explored by controlling surface binding interactions. Targeting nanoparticles to utilize them for special applications with enhanced catalytic, electronic, optical and magnetic properties is highly dependent on organizing and positioning them in functional context [6], which may find optimum use in devices with high catalytic performance. Preparation of functionalized cells has been carried out to produce biogenic CaCO3 nanoscale scaffolds and it is mentioned that such nanoparticles possess enviable properties of functionalized cells in order to meet the principle of use in many fields such as medicine, environmental and material sciences [7]. Similarly hierarchical CaCO3–maltose materials were also prepared to investigate their decontamination capacities for removal of pollutants from waters, such nanostructures found to highly active for remediation of many metal ions [8]. In our previous report method l-mehonine was used as capping agent for the synthesis of Ni NWs for the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of isopropyl alcohol to acetone [9]. Whereas in the present work we applied organic dye (Congo red) as model compound to monitor the catalytic efficiency of fabricated l-threonine capped Ni NPs. Regarding the toxic effect of dyes, studies have been carried out that show the extensive release of a number of azo dyes (such as CR) from effluents of the textile industry and many other sources which cause aquatic environmental pollution leading to severe health complications in amphibians and aquatic life [10]. Several methodologies have been introduced to decontaminate waters including biodegradation, ion exchange and adsorption on activated carbon and clays [11–13]. However, these pollution control processes are insufficient because they simply transfer the hazards from one phase to another and require further costs for treatments (e.g. incineration or land filling) to destroy the end product [14]. On the other hand a common exploitation of CR dye is its histological use for amyloid detection. Its specificity of staining results from the affinity for the binding of CR dye with fibril proteins in the β-sheet conformation. It has recently been observed that the dye also interferes in processes such as protein misfolding and aggregation, stabilizing partially folded intermediates and native protein monomers, during decrease in concentration of additional toxic protein oligomers [15]. A more advantageous application of CR analogs is their use in development of imaging probes. The small molecular size and penetrability of CR congeners through blood-brain barriers provide the basis to utilize the dye for in vivo and antemortem visualization and brain amyloid quantification [15]. Despite its useful aspects, CR is a highly objectionable dye due to its extensive contribution to aquatic pollution by producing unwanted colored water that is a real threat for aquatic life and for use by humans. Considering the hazardous impacts of the dye, we have synthesized small Ni NPs via a greener route that possess tremendous potential as catalytic materials to completely degrade CR dye, which can be taken as a model for other degradable dyes. Moreover the fabricated Ni NPs are easy to recover and can be reused without any loss in activity suggesting the non-poisonous aspect of Ni NPs with high economy. The fabrication route does not require high energy, extended preparation time or special equipment and the resulting Ni NPs are of small size with highly narrow size distributions and homogeneous morphologies. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and reagents Nanoparticle synthesis and application was carried out using NiCl2·6H2O (97%), purchased from E. Merck, l-threonine (99%), from Fluka Chemicals, and NaBH4 (98%), NaOH (98%), HCl (37%) and CR dye (99%), from Sigma–Aldrich. All chemicals were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Pure Milli-Q water was used as the preparatory medium. 2.2 Preparation of stock solutions Stock solutions of 0.1M NiCl2·6H2O, 0.1M l-threonine and 0.5M NaBH4 were prepared in 100ml volumetric flasks using the required quantities of each and diluted to the mark with Milli-Q water. Further 1M NaOH and 1M HCl were also prepared to adjust the pH of freshly prepared sample solutions of Ni NPs in aqueous media. CR dye was dissolved in Milli-Q water to prepare 1mM of its stock solution to carry out experiments for the catalytic performance of Ni NPs for reduction/degradation of dye. 2.3 Procedure for fabrication of Ni NPs and sample preparation for UV–vis spectroscopy In a typical experiment, a 10ml sample of Ni NPs in Milli-Q water was prepared by mixing 0.1ml (0.1M) NiCl2·6H2O and 0.5ml (0.5M) NaBH4 under gentle stirring using a magnetic stirrer. The solution turned dark brown in color during the addition of the reducing agent (NaBH4). Then 1.2ml (0.05M) of l-threonine was mixed in the solution instantly and the pH of the solution was adjusted to 8.5 using the required amounts of 1M NaOH. The mixture was left for 10–15min to ensure the completion of reduction and encapsulation of nickel ions to form neutral nanoscale objects. The solution was analyzed by UV–vis spectroscopy and it was found that the as-prepared sample of Ni NPs was stable for several hours. 2.4 Nanoparticle separation As-prepared l-threonine capped Ni NPs obtained in an aqueous medium were separated by means of high speed centrifugation using a KUBOTA 7780 refrigerated centrifuge, operated at 22,000rpm. The Ni NPs were collected at the bottom of the centrifuge tube, separated by decanting off the solvent and washed several times with Milli-Q water followed by thorough washing with acetone. These Ni NPs were obtained with 99% purity by density gradient ultracentrifugation from an aqueous medium and redispersed in ethanol by sonication on an ultrasonic device and collected in separate glass bottles, remaining stable for several days. 2.5 Instrumentation The UV–vis spectroscopy measurements taken during experiments to fabricate Ni NPs samples were performed using a double beam Lambda 35 spectrophotometer (Perkin Elmer) equipped with a cell of 1.0cm path length. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of standard l-threonine and of Ni NPs capped with l-threonine molecules were recorded using a Nicolet 5700 (Thermo) using KBr discs of solid state amino acid standard and nanopowders. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) images were recorded using a Dimension 3100 AFM and Nanoscope IV controller (Veeco Instruments). Transmission electron micrographs (TEM) were taken with a JEOL JEM 1200 EX MKI operated at 120kV and magnifications up to 500,000. 2.6 Sample preparation for FTIR studies Solid state Ni NPs capped with l-threonine were separated from colloidal dispersions by putting large quantities of these products into petri dishes and drying within a hot water bath set to 80°C until complete evaporation of the solvent, with further drying in an oven at 100°C for 30min to confirm evaporation of residual solvent and water molecules. As-obtained Ni NPs samples were collected by scratching the NPs from surface of petri dishes and processed for FTIR spectroscopy. 2.7 Sample preparation for AFM studies 10μl volumes of colloidal l-threonine capped Ni NPs dispersions in ethanol solvent were put on glass cover slips and vacuum dried in a desiccator followed by air drying for 30min to ensure binding of Ni NPs with the glass surface and thorough loss of water molecules. 2.8 Sample preparation for TEM studies Small quantities of colloidal dispersions of l-threonine capped Ni NPs in ethanol solvent were mounted on carbon coated copper grids (300 mesh Cu, EM Science) by a dip coating method and forwarded for vacuum drying in a desiccator for 30min to ensure that solvent water/ethanol had been removed. 2.9 Catalytic test for reduction of dye The catalytic activity of newly synthesized l-threonine capped Ni NPs was investigated for reduction/degradation of CR by putting a solution having 20μM concentration of dye and 100mM NaBH4 in quartz cells and diagnosed with the help of UV–vis spectroscopy. Ni NPs were first deposited on broken pieces of glass cover slips and dried by heating to get fine attachment with the surface of glass. These glass cover slips were weighed before and after deposition of Ni NPs to find out the weight of deposited Ni nanocatalysts. The cover slips with appropriate weight were put inside the quartz cell containing the dye and NaBH4 containing solution. UV–vis spectra were recorded for various experiments to see the reduction of the CR dye. Optimizations of various parameters like molar concentration of dye (20μM CR), reducing agent (100mM NaBH4), loading quantity of the catalyst (0.2mg Ni NPs), reaction time (50s) and yield of reduction (100%) at fixed NPs quantity were carried out. 3 Results and discussions We introduced a method for fabrication of well dispersed spherical Ni NPs consisting of amino acid layers on the nanoparticle surfaces. Evidence for fabrication of Ni NPs has been demonstrated by several characterization techniques. 3.1 UV–vis spectroscopy UV–vis spectra based on the variation of l-threonine concentrations with respect to the constant concentration of precursor Ni are shown in Fig. 1 . A continuous blue is recorded upon the increase in concentration of l-threonine which indicates the formation of smaller Ni NPs at high concentration of capping agent. In the absence of capping agent the reduced nickel ions form atomic nickel which then undergoes nucleation to produce strongly bound homo atomic aggregates of tiny black particles. On the other hand, the addition of l-threonine immediately after the addition of sodium borohydride to nickel chloride solution resulted in the formation of relatively stable black colloidal dispersions. The l-threonine molecules were naturally sorbed on the surface of nanocomposites via the amino group which subsequently helped in the growth patterning of these nanocomposites into spherical shapes. As-obtained colloidal dispersions of Ni NPs in aqueous environments were then separated by high speed centrifugation and redispersed into ethanol and found to be highly stable for several months; however, freshly fabricated Ni NPs were comparatively unstable in aqueous environments. The physisorption of l-threonine molecules onto the particle surfaces showed strong dependency on the solution medium, which might be due to the zwitterionic property of amino acid molecules, that is their tendency to form doubly charged ions. This is necessarily the case in favor of smaller non-covalently bonded l-threonine molecules at the surface of Ni NPs. 3.2 Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy FTIR spectra for l-threonine and Ni NPs capped with l-threonine molecules are shown in Fig. 2 . These spectra provide supporting evidence for nanofabricated architectures estimated by underlying homogeneous distributions realized through UV–vis spectroscopic studies and those shown in AFM images. The FTIR spectrum of pure l-threonine (Fig. 2a) illustrates a zwitterionic band at 2050cm−1 that is absent in the FTIR spectrum of Ni NPs (Fig. 2b). IR spectra of nickel nanocomposites show two broad and strong signals at 1630cm−1 and 1390cm−1 which can be assigned to hydroxyl groups [16,17]. Similar peaks have been seen at 1651cm−1 and 1382cm−1 by other workers [18]. The complex spectral bands below 1500cm−1 are assigned to CH bending vibrations resulting from methylene and methyl groups and the weak IR signals in the range 1200–1050cm−1 can be attributed to CN stretching due to the presence of amino groups [19]. This is also clear from the FTIR spectra recorded for standard l-threonine and Ni NPs as shown in Fig. 2. That one broad band above 3000cm−1 is present with no changes corresponding to the presence of OH (3400cm−1) and NH (3170cm−1) stretching frequencies experienced by –COOH and –NH2 groups. This confirms the surface binding of nanoscale nickel composites via amino linkages. In the light of the whole study it is confirmed that the amino group of the amino acid is interacted with Ni NPs and hence this group is responsible for the formation of nanoparticles. 3.3 Atomic force microscopy (AFM) AFM micrographs present highly distributed Ni NPs grown after capping with l-threonine molecules on glass cover slips as shown in Fig. 3 . One of the most useful aspects of atomic force microscopy is its ability to measure quantitative special dimensions of a variety of surface features like small particles deposited on a substrate or etch pits. Size homogeneity and nanoscale dimensions of the as prepared Ni NPs were examined using AFM as well as TEM data which were found to be in good agreement. Fig. 4 presents the size distribution, color changes in Ni NPs solution and mechanistic diagram of the formation of Ni NPs via specific interactions. AFM analysis reveals that the products correspond to well dispersed and roughened surface nanoscale nickel particles. We present different colors and percent numbers to state the size distribution of l-threonine capped Ni NPs, revealing a major contribution of 34.66% of Ni NPs with sizes 5.08nm, 30.75% of 4.49nm, 23.06% of 3.37nm and 11.51% of 1.68nm respectively. Each amino acid molecule could be individually attached at the surface of small nanocomposites and the final structure undoubtedly follows a similar shape. 3.4 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) High resolution TEM is used to examine the size and shape of very small nanoscale objects and is also helpful to investigate the structure and chemistry of nanomaterials [20,21]. A sample of powdered Ni NPs dispersed in ethanol using an ultrasonic device and mounted on carbon coated copper grids was prepared to carry out TEM characterization as presented in Fig. 5 . The nanoscale nickel structures are known to have a tendency to connect with each other through their magnetic dipole interaction [22]. Therefore, it is very difficult to prepare isolated magnetic nanoparticles as the particles undergo agglomeration easily [15]. In order to stop agglomeration, we employed l-threonine to cap the Ni NPs via nitrogen atoms which resulted in the formation of one dimensional assemblies of reduced nickel atoms and agglomeration was minimized as evidenced by the AFM images. The variation in structure and assembly apparent in the AFM and TEM images is due to the use of different substrates, glass in the case of AFM and carbon coated copper grids for the TEM. Similar variations based on differences in the substrate nature have been reported with SEM and TEM [23]. 3.5 Chemical properties of congo red Congo red (C32H22N6O6S2, MW-696.7) is a linear symmetrical molecule. It possesses a hydrophobic center made up of two phenyl rings bound together via diazo (–NN–) linkages with two charged terminal naphthalene moieties which contain sulfonic acid (–HSO3) and amino (–NH2) groups as shown in Fig. 6 . The CR dye molecule is approximately 2.1nm in diameter which on dissociation via diazo linkages produces chinone and sulfonazo forms [15] as depicted in Fig. 6b and c. 3.6 Catalytic activity UV–vis spectral studies were carried out to check the performance of freshly prepared Ni NPs for the catalytic reduction/degradation of CR dye as illustrated in Fig. 7 . We observed high catalytic efficiency of the l threonine capped Ni NPs fabricated by our newly introduced rapid and inexpensive synthetic route. Fig. 7a reveals the absorption profile of CR dye in Milli-Q water. It is observed that peaks at 498nm, 348nm and 238nm were stable and did not undergo structural transformations initially under UV–vis irradiations alone even after one hour of irradiation. However, we observed the process of decolorization/degradation of dye after addition of Ni NPs catalyst, in the presence of sodium borohydride. The spectra are shown with respect to time (Fig. 7b). The UV–vis spectral studies suggest the complete degradation of the CR dye within 50s which highlights the exceptional catalytic potential of the Ni NPs. The degradation of the dye was characterized by a steady decrease in absorption at 498nm and 348nm which are estimated to be attacked by electrons on the nitrogen double bonds located principally at 348nm [24]. The UV–vis spectra were recorded periodically and we found gradual decreases in absorption at 498nm and 348nm, whereas completely inverse behavior at 278nm and 249nm (regular increases) was observed, which is attributed to the formation of smaller structural units. This characteristic behavior of CR dye resulted from the addition of NaBH4 under the influence of Ni NPs catalyst. UV–vis spectra also showed isobestic points in the spectral profiles around 300nm, a clear indication for degradation of large dye molecules to smaller fragments, i.e. low molecular weight compounds. 3.7 Recovery and reuse of Ni NPs catalyst The newly devised protocol to fabricate and use l-threonine capped Ni NPs for catalytic reduction degradation of congo red dye demonstrates simple and effortless recovery to reuse these nanoparticles several times. A bar graph presenting the clear picture of high catalytic efficiency of l-threonine capped Ni NPs after even five times use is shown in Fig. 8 . The same NPs reduced/degraded 20μM congo red dye within 50s each time. Ni NPs used for catalytic application were deposited on pieces of glass cover slips which were easily recovered after use and washed with sufficient quantity of deionized water followed by drying on hot plate already set at 100°C (for 10min) to remove water vapors. We observed negligible/no loss of activity for the reduction reaction. 4 Conclusions It is suggested that simplicity, cost effectiveness and safety of the present nanoparticle fabrication route supersedes numerous procedures to manufacture well dispersed Ni NPs with spherical shapes. Appropriate amounts of NaOH/HCl were added to adjust the pH in the range 2.6–11.3; however, the basic pH 8.5 was found to favor the formation of spherical and well dispersed Ni NPs as shown in TEM micrographs. The microscope studies reveal that bigger Ni NPs are formed from small individual nanocomposites with fine crystalline structures. Freshly prepared Ni NPs deposited on glass surfaces produce significantly high yields for catalytic performance. We observed complete degradation of 20μM concentrations of dye with 0.1M NaBH4 within 50s during the course of reaction under UV–vis irradiation in the presence of nanoparticles. The Ni NPs have been found easy to recover and reuse several times without loss of activity. Acknowledgments We acknowledge the Higher Education Commission, Islamabad, Pakistan and the University of Bristol, Bristol, United Kingdom for provision of funding and facilities during this research. Thanks go to Dr. Sean Davis and Dr. Loren Picco of the University of Bristol, Bristol, United Kingdom for their kind assistance with microscopy studies. References [1] J.E. coredata.dc:description: A facile and green seed mediated growth approach for fabrication of well dispersed l-threonine derived nickel nanoparticles (Ni NPs) in an aqueous medium via a modified borohydride reduction method is described. l-Threonine molecules served to organize the nanoscale composites in the form of well dispersed Ni NPs. The basic pH 8.5 was found to favor the formation of spherical and well dispersed Ni NPs as shown in transmission electron microscopy (TEM) micrographs. Freshly prepared Ni NPs possess the nanoscale dimension of 1.68–5.06nm, as determined from atomic force microscopy (AFM) and TEM data. The Ni NPs thus prepared were used for their catalytic potential in the reduction of congo red (CR) dye selected as a model reagent. The results revealed negligible reduction of dye in the absence of Ni NPs. Conversely the addition of only 0.2mg Ni NPs produced 100% reduction/degradation efficiency. The used Ni NPs were recovered and reutilized several times for reducing CR without any loss of activity. The current findings are equally extendable for safeguarding the aquatic environment against the pollution caused by other dyes via a facile, highly economical, rapid and efficient reduction/degradation method based on the catalytic potential of Ni NPs.

coredata.dc:title: Fabrication of small l-threonine capped nickel nanoparticles and their catalytic application
